title: How to send a text message and make it look like it came from someone else phone number - Quora

response.answer_text: In the US — you cannot. Let me clarify that — while it is technically very easy to do, it is practically impossible, because no provider will let you send a text from a number not registered with them or otherwise verified as being associated with you. You can buy your own equipment, write your own code, use a service — none of that matters. At the end of the day — that message needs to be sent through a provider, and that provider will require sender verification. Now, you can obtain a number from a number vendor (there are plenty around, free ones like GoogleVoice or paid ones) and then obtain a service (from the same source or a different one) that will allow you to send texts out. But it will be your number, not someone else’s. And you will only be able to send that number as caller ID. It will still be associated with you, and traceable. It just won’t be your personal cell number, that’s all. As others have said, spoofing a caller ID on a text message is illegal, and it carries hefty fines and, possibly, jail time (depending on your jurisdiction). Plus it may result in the carrier that allowed this coming under FCC scrutiny. Which is why they don’t allow it. It’s OK to have multiple numbers and to use them for communication. It’s not OK to pretend to be someone you are not.

I think it is correct that you can not fake other known person’s number. But there is way of similar approaches. I have ever purchased another phone number, mark it in my contacts as “Santa Claus”. And then, at the Christmas Eve I set up a greeting text message automatically sent to my personal phone number at midnight, and told my kids Santa came to watch them. You can use the same way to mark that number as Justin Bieber, Bill Gates, Donald Trump, your CEO’s name… whoever you like. The key points for the successful game are, 1) You can buy and release 2nd phone number with low cost, and, 2) The texts can be sent from that 2nd number at the right time in a secret way. The best case shall be without your intervention. Try the app called AutoSender in AppStore, if you have iPhone/iPad device. These 2 points are all met. And yes you can also use TextNow, or TextMe, etc. to get 2nd number for texting, but with them you have to send texts manually. Simply search “auto text” or “Automatic text” or “auto SMS” in AppStore, you will get it on top.

Without more information, perhaps a slightly different question would be ‘how did someone send a text that appeared to come from my cellphone’ Note that it isn’t too hard for someone with the right equipment to send out a text message with a spoof sending address - there are APIs that a cellular network is likely to have that allow approved senders to send texts (just as you may get a text from a number in the cellular operator telling you that your latest bill is ready to view: it won’t come from a mobile phone) - it depends on how able the cellular system is to verify the sender. There is a similar capability in faking the ‘from’ line in e-mails - it requires an ISP to verify the sender.

I’d be in a better position to answer you when reading your reply to the question at the end of my reply. Whatever it is that you are doing, which now requires dishonesty like that, will most likely lead you to places that are pretty dark. Unless you are an Engineer of some sort my question to you is… What are you doing that requires this?

Here’s one way: Buy a corporate level switchboard or phone trunk software solution that allows you to send out a different number than the individual number calling. Hire an expert to configure it, generally $150 or more per hour, takes a couple days (if you could do it yourself, you wouldn’t be asking here). This is what most phone/text robocallers, fraudsters and spammers do. But it’s also dead normal for a corporate switchboard, which is why it’s such a hard problem for the FCC to kill spam and fraud over phone lines. However, none of these methods are foolproof. The caller ID will show the spoofed number but the phone company will still have your metadata. If you are misbehaving you can still go to jail. And that’s true for basically any method involving a phone line. If you’re planning on it for any black market or malicious reason, I’d advise against.

There are apps in most app stores that provide you with a “burner number”. It’s not really so much a burner number as it is a second phone number that is connected to the same cellular device. If you go into your apps store and you search ““fake number apps”, one that fits your needs will most likely pop up. But be warned, most of the apps have software that is severely outdated and, in turn, makes the application run slow. And the newer ones are available for purchase. But in any case, they do work and will send to any real number as long as you provide the area code to said number you are trying to reach.

response.answer_text: You will require SS7 access to a mobile network, then you can easily spoof  a number in an SMS header.  Also, this is a dick move.

Not sure why I’m getting A2A on a 4 year old question, but since I did, here goes… Under the Truth in Caller ID Act, FCC rules prohibit any person or entity from transmitting misleading or inaccurate caller ID information with the intent to defraud, cause harm, or wrongly obtain anything of value. The important phrase in there is “intent to defraud”, which includes the intent to deceive someone about your identity. So, at least in the USA, it is almost certainly illegal to falsify the number you’re using. If someone decided to prosecute you for it, you’d better have a good lawyer.

They didn’t. What they did was send you a text from a service like TextNow that lets the sender enter any phone number they want for the “from”. You cannot rely only the “from” number as being accurate in any way. No, there is no way to get a “real” number - TextNow is a web service that may not involve any phone at all.

How can I send a text message to someone else's phone number? First you add the recipients number to the address field of your text app. The message you wish to send is typed out in the box below that. When you have finished writing the message, hit send. The message is them transmitted to the recipient and you have sent your first text message to someone else's phone.
